instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message:
Appreciate any and all help, thanks!

So I've got a logic board where the board turns on (and green light is displayed) randomly meaning I have to plug in and out the charger before it suddenly turns on. When the fan starts spinning the green light cycles from on and off every couple of seconds and then turns solid eventually the fan then spins at like maximum rpm (the chipset SLJBC gets really warm which I why I believe that might be)
In all cases (green light or no):
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is present.
PP3V42 is present.
No display in LCD.

Thank you,
Sam

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message: How warm is warm? You should be able to hold your finger on it without issues.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message: It gets unusually hot, not bad enough to burn fingers though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message: Well if it gets much hotter than a good working board it is most likely dead. Compare to another board first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message:
The component F9700 has 12.57V showing at the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and giving 1.8V which slowly declines at the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_FUSED</SIGNAL> end. All the connections to the <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT</SIGNAL> gives a value of around 1.42V

Also answering your question it does get hotter than a similar board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message:
I don't see why we should be checking the backlight fuse if this board is not booting.

I suspect the PCH is dead if it getting hot like that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message:
Is there anything else I can check for to confirm that the PCH being dead is more likely?

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message: PP3V42, PPBUS, ACOK, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. But if the PCH is pretty sure dead that is where you should really start....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message: What would be the best way forward for this, buy the chip online or to use the chip from a similar donor board (from one that doesn't show similar symptoms)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Intermittent green light, no display.
threads.message: These chips don't commonly die so most donor ones will be OK, they are a bit annoying to reball though.
